children.subject: I feel like this misses OP's point. There's more to life than grades, after all.
You got desired grades, so cheer up and you will do great in the future as well!

history.content: There are peer advisors available for both L&S CS and EECS students in the fall, but I'm not sure whether we have them available during the summer. I am going to look and see what options we have for you. This is a good question. I will come back with an answer.

children.subject: Hi! I just wanted to say I'm sorry you had such a bad school year, it really sucks. Grades definitely do not define how you should feel. I'm sure you know that you are not alone in feeling this way, but that doesn't really fix the situation. I hope things get better for you :). Just wanted to pass on a little encouragement and acknowledge you from one stressed-out undergrad to another. At least in person class is on the horizon.

history.content:
I had a pretty bad school year (got the grades I wanted to in all of my classes, but dealt with a lot of things transitioning to online school that affected my ability to perform to my best academically, or perform without feeling stressed/pressured). 

I don't really feel comfortable with the way I did things academically, though, like in my perspective I failed to adjust academically to a remote setting of school, had one of the hardest school years personally, made some mistakes as a person, and did not study efficiently. Maybe overexercised asking for help through the blur that comes with being isolated, lost control of things, felt disconnected from school, and made relatively weak decisions. I was not on campus, stayed at home for the duration of COVID and had disconnected socially. 

I know that graduate students have EECS Peers (https://www2.eecs.berkeley.edu/eecs-peers/?_ga=2.54045544.1941193769.1624062203-260871874.1620723996) but I'm not sure if undergraduates have this available, or if there is any undergrad I can talk to. I think an undergraduate student who has gone through Berkeley EECS might understand me better than a generic counselor (the one person I did speak to in engineering counseling (Christine Zhou) at one point in the past didn't really understand the climate I was in or my circumstances specifically so I don't know how useful it would be for me to go to her.). Basically, how do achieving students get help in times of stress?

I think once I'm back on campus, I'll probably be more optimistic and forget about the things that currently bother me, but for now I feel like I sometimes have periods of unproductivity due to the stuff I went through the past year, and insecurity over the internet, that is affecting my own confidence to perform precisely/stick to a schedule.
